exerciseContent.content:
HTML Headings üìù

Headings allow you to structure your content hierarchically. HTML offers six levels, from <h1> (most important) to <h6> (least important).

Why are they important?

  • SEO: Search engines use headings to understand your page structure.
  • Accessibility: Screen readers use them to navigate content.
  • Visuals: Browsers apply default sizing (big to small).

Note: Only use one <h1> per page for the main title!
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Let's build a structure for a news article.

  1. Change the text inside the <h1> to 'Daily News'.
  2. Add an <h2> tag below it with the text 'Breaking Story'.
  3. Add an <h3> tag below that with the text 'Local Updates'.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Your code should look like a ladder: <h1> first, then <h2>, then <h3>. Don't forget the closing tags like </h2>!

/index.html.code: Title Here

exerciseContent.output: A page displaying 'Daily News' (large), 'Breaking Story' (medium), and 'Local Updates' (small)

exerciseContent.content:
Structuring Text ‚úçÔ∏è

The <p> tag defines a paragraph. It automatically adds space before and after the text.

Formatting Text

You can emphasize specific words inside a paragraph:

  • <strong>: Makes text bold (indicates importance).
  • <em>: Makes text italic (indicates emphasis).
  • <br>: Inserts a single line break (useful for poems or addresses).
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

  1. Create a <p> tag with the text: 'I love coding.'
  2. Wrap the word 'love' in a <strong> tag.
  3. Create a second <p> tag with the text: 'HTML is fun!'
  4. Wrap 'fun' in an <em> tag.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Nesting tags looks like this: <p>This is <strong>bold</strong> text.</p>

/index.html.code:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Paragraphs & Text</title>
</head>
<body>
  
  
</body>
</html>

exerciseContent.output: Two paragraphs with bold and italicized words respectively

exerciseContent.content:
Connecting the Web üîó

The <a> (anchor) tag creates hyperlinks. The most important attribute is href, which tells the browser where the link goes.

<a href="https://google.com">Go to Google</a>

To open a link in a new tab, add target="_blank".
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Create a navigation list:

  1. Create a link to 'https://www.google.com' with the text 'Search'.
  2. Make the Google link open in a new tab.
  3. Create a second link to 'contact.html' with the text 'Contact Us'.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: The syntax is <a href="url" target="_blank">Link Text</a>.

/index.html.code: My Links

exerciseContent.output: Two clickable links, one opening in a new tab

exerciseContent.content:
A Picture is Worth 1000 Words üñºÔ∏è

Use the <img> tag to embed images. It is a self-closing tag (no closing tag needed).

Key Attributes:

  • src: The source URL of the image.
  • alt: Alternative text description (crucial for accessibility and if the image fails to load).
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Add a cute coding mascot to the page.

  • Use the <img> tag.
  • Set src to 'https://bit.ly/codebox-mascot'.
  • Set alt to 'A happy coding robot'.
  • Set the width attribute to '200'.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Remember, img tags don't have a closing </img>. Just <img src="..." alt="..." />.

/index.html.code: Our Mascot

exerciseContent.output: An image displayed on the page with width 200px

exerciseContent.content:
Organizing Content with Lists üìã

HTML offers two main types of lists:

  • Unordered List (`<ul>`): Uses bullet points. Good for grocery lists.
  • Ordered List (`<ol>`): Uses numbers (1, 2, 3). Good for recipes or instructions.

Both types use <li> (list item) tags for the actual items.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

  1. Create an <h3> named 'Shopping List'.
  2. Below it, create a <ul> with 3 items: Milk, Eggs, Bread.
  3. Create an <h3> named 'Top 3 Languages'.
  4. Below it, create an <ol> with 3 items: HTML, CSS, JavaScript.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: The <li> tags must go inside the <ul> or <ol> tags.

/index.html.code:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Lists</title>
</head>
<body>
  
  
</body>
</html>

exerciseContent.output: One bulleted list and one numbered list

exerciseContent.content:
Structuring Data üìä

Tables allow you to arrange data into rows and columns.

Table Structure:

  • <table>: The wrapper.
  • <tr>: Table Row.
  • <th>: Table Header (bold and centered).
  • <td>: Table Data (standard cell).
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Create a table of employees.

  1. Create a <table>.
  2. Add a first row (<tr>) with two headers (<th>): 'Name' and 'Role'.
  3. Add a second row with data (<td>): 'Alice' and 'Developer'.
  4. Add a third row with data: 'Bob' and 'Designer'.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Every row must be wrapped in <tr> tags. The first row usually contains <th>, subsequent rows contain <td>.

/index.html.code:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Tables</title>
</head>
<body>
  
  
</body>
</html>

exerciseContent.output: A 3-row table with headers and data cells

exerciseContent.content:
Collecting User Input üìù

Forms are how users interact with your website. The <form> element wraps all input controls.

Key elements:

  • <input>: Single line field (self-closing).
  • <label>: Describes the input (for accessibility).
  • <button>: Submits the form.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Create a login form:

  1. Create a <form> tag.
  2. Inside, add a <label> with text 'Username:'.
  3. Add an <input> of type 'text'.
  4. Add a <button> with text 'Login'.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Inputs usually don't have text inside them. Use the placeholder attribute if you want hint text, or a label next to it.

/index.html.code: Login

exerciseContent.output: A functional form with a label, input field, and button

exerciseContent.content:
The Many Faces of Input üé≠

The type attribute changes how an input behaves. Common types:

  • text: Standard text.
  • password: Hides characters (***).
  • email: Validates email format.
  • number: Numeric input only.
  • date: Date picker.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Enhance the registration form by adding these inputs inside the form:

  1. An input with type 'password' and placeholder 'Secret Code'.
  2. An input with type 'email' and placeholder 'you@web.com'.
  3. An input with type 'number' for Age.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Use the placeholder attribute to show ghost text inside the box: <input type="email" placeholder="..." />.

/index.html.code: Sign Up

exerciseContent.output: Form displaying password, email, and number inputs

exerciseContent.content:
Keep it Clean üõ°Ô∏è

HTML5 allows you to validate data before it is sent to a server using attributes:

  • required: The field cannot be empty.
  • min / max: Limits for numbers.
  • minlength: Minimum character count.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Secure the existing form:

  1. Make the Username required.
  2. Set the Age input to have a min of 18 and max of 99.
  3. Make the Password require a minlength of 8 characters.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: These are attributes without values (booleans) or with values. Example: <input type="text" required minlength="5" />.

/index.html.code:
Username:
Age:
Password:

exerciseContent.output: Form that prevents submission if rules (like empty username or age < 18) are violated

exerciseContent.content:
Meaningful Markup üß†

Semantic elements describe what they are, not just how they look. This is vital for accessibility and SEO.

Common Tags:

  • <header>: Intro content or nav.
  • <main>: The primary content.
  • <footer>: Copyright, contact info.
  • <article>: Independent content (blog post).
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Replace the generic <div> tags in the starter code with the correct semantic tags: <header>, <main>, and <footer>.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Look at the IDs on the divs (id="header") to guess which semantic tag to use.

/index.html.code:
My Website

Welcome to my semantic page.

© 2023 Me

exerciseContent.output: Code structure using header, main, and footer tags instead of divs

exerciseContent.content:
Building the Big Picture üèóÔ∏è

A professional webpage combines semantic tags to create a standard layout.

  • <nav>: For navigation links.
  • <section>: Thematic grouping of content.
  • <aside>: Sidebar content (ads, related links).
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Build a blog layout structure inside the <body>:

  1. A <header> containing a <nav>.
  2. A <main> area.
  3. Inside main, an <article> and an <aside>.
  4. A <footer> at the bottom.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Think of it as boxes inside boxes. The Article and Aside sit side-by-side (conceptually) inside the Main box.

/index.html.code:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>HTML5 Layout</title>
</head>
<body>
  

</body>
</html>

exerciseContent.output: A complete semantic document structure

exerciseContent.content:
Introduction to CSS üé®

CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) controls the look of your HTML.

Syntax:

selector {
  property: value;
}

Example: h1 { color: red; } turns all h1 headings red.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Style the page in the styles.css file:

  1. Select the h1 tag.
  2. Set its color to blue.
  3. Select the p tag.
  4. Set its color to green.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Make sure to write your code in the styles.css tab, not the HTML file!

/index.html.code:
Hello CSS

Making things pretty.

exerciseContent.output: Blue heading and green paragraph

exerciseContent.content:
Targeting Elements üéØ

You can target elements in three main ways:

  • Type: p {} (Targets all paragraphs)
  • Class: .classname {} (Targets reusable groups)
  • ID: #idname {} (Targets a unique element)

Classes use a dot, IDs use a hash.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

  1. In styles.css, select the class .highlight and set background-color: yellow.
  2. Select the ID #unique and set color: red.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: In HTML, the class is defined as class="highlight", but in CSS you select it as .highlight.

/index.html.code:
This is important.

This is normal.

This is unique.

/styles.css.code: /* Target the class and ID below */

exerciseContent.output: Yellow background on one paragraph, red text on another

exerciseContent.content:
Painting the Web üñåÔ∏è

CSS supports color names ('red'), Hex codes ('#FF0000'), and RGB values.

Properties:

  • color: Changes text color.
  • background-color: Changes the background.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Make the card look nice:

  1. Select the .card class.
  2. Give it a background-color of #f0f0f0 (light gray).
  3. Give it a text color of #333333 (dark gray).
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Hex codes always start with a #. Don't forget the semicolon at the end of the line!

/index.html.code:
User Profile

Welcome back!

exerciseContent.output: A light gray card with dark gray text

exerciseContent.content:
Styling Text üÖ∞Ô∏è

Make your text readable and stylish.

  • font-family: The font type (Arial, serif, monospace).
  • font-size: Size of text (px, rem).
  • font-weight: Thickness (bold, normal, 400, 700).
  • text-align: Alignment (left, center, right).
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Style the h1 heading:

  1. Set font to sans-serif.
  2. Set size to 36px.
  3. Align it to the center.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: The property is text-align, not just 'align'.

/index.html.code:
Headline

Content goes here.

exerciseContent.output: Centered, large, sans-serif heading

exerciseContent.content:
Everything is a Box üì¶

Every element in HTML is a box wrapped in layers:

  1. Content: The actual text/image.
  2. Padding: Space inside the border.
  3. Border: The line around the padding.
  4. Margin: Space outside the border.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Define the box model for the .box div:

  1. Add a 5px solid black border.
  2. Add 20px of padding.
  3. Add 30px of margin.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Border syntax is shorthand: width style color.

/index.html.code:
I am a box
I am another box

exerciseContent.output: Two blue boxes separated by space, with internal spacing and borders

exerciseContent.content:
Spacing in Depth üìè

You can control specific sides of an element.

  • padding-top, margin-left, etc.
  • Shorthand: margin: 10px 20px; (10px Top/Bottom, 20px Left/Right).

Centering: To center a block element horizontally, use margin: 0 auto; (requires a width).
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Center the container:

  1. Give .container a width of 300px.
  2. Center it using margin: 0 auto.
  3. Give it 20px padding on all sides.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: 0 auto means 0 margin on top/bottom, and automatic margin on left/right (which centers it).

/index.html.code: I am centered content.

exerciseContent.output: A pink box centered horizontally in the preview window

exerciseContent.content:
Block vs. Inline üß±

The display property controls behavior:

  • block: Takes full width, starts new line (e.g., div, p).
  • inline: Takes only needed width, no height/width setting (e.g., span, a).
  • inline-block: Flows like text, but allows height/width.
  • none: Hides the element completely.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

  1. Change the list items li to display: inline-block to make a horizontal menu.
  2. Set the class .hidden-msg to display: none.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: By default, list items are block elements (vertical). Changing them to inline-block makes them sit side-by-side.

/index.html.code:
• Home
  • About
  • Contact
You shouldn't see me!

exerciseContent.output: Horizontal menu items and hidden text

exerciseContent.content:
Precise Placement üìç

The position property breaks elements out of normal flow.

  • relative: Offset from its normal spot.
  • absolute: Positioned relative to the nearest positioned ancestor.
  • fixed: Stays in place when scrolling.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Create a notification badge.

  1. Set .container to position: relative.
  2. Set .badge to position: absolute.
  3. Move the badge to the top right corner: top: 0, right: 0.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Absolute items look for the nearest parent with 'relative' (or absolute/fixed) position to use as their anchor point.

/index.html.code: 1

exerciseContent.output: A button with a red notification badge on its top-right corner

exerciseContent.content:
Flexbox Layout üí™

Flexbox is a one-dimensional layout method. To start, add display: flex to a parent container.

Main Axis alignment (justify-content):

  • flex-start (default)
  • center
  • space-between
  • flex-end
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Arrange the navigation items.

  1. Set .nav-bar to display: flex.
  2. Space them out evenly using justify-content: space-between.
  3. Align them vertically using align-items: center.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: justify-content works on the main axis (horizontal usually), align-items works on the cross axis (vertical).

/index.html.code:
Logo
Link 1
Link 2

exerciseContent.output: Items spread across the bar with the Logo on left and Link 2 on right

exerciseContent.content:
Wrapping and Growing üå±

By default, flex items try to fit on one line. Use flex-wrap: wrap to allow them to break to new lines.

Use flex: 1 on a child to make it grow to fill available space.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Build a sidebar layout.

  1. Set .container to display: flex.
  2. Give .sidebar a width of 200px.
  3. Give .content the property flex: 1 so it takes the remaining space.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: flex: 1 is a magic shortcut that makes an element 'greedy'‚Äîit eats up all empty space.

/index.html.code:
Sidebar
Main Content Area

exerciseContent.output: A fixed-width sidebar next to a content area that fills the screen

exerciseContent.content:
2D Layouts with Grid üï∏Ô∏è

CSS Grid handles both rows and columns simultaneously.

.container {
  display: grid;
  grid-template-columns: 100px 100px 100px;
  grid-gap: 10px;
}

Use 1fr (fraction) to create flexible columns.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Create a 3-column photo gallery.

  1. Set .gallery to display: grid.
  2. Create 3 equal columns using grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr.
  3. Add a 20px gap between items using grid-gap.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: 1fr means 'one part of the available space'. Three columns of 1fr means each takes 33%.

/index.html.code:
Img 1
Img 2
Img 3

exerciseContent.output: Three orange boxes in a row with spacing between them

exerciseContent.content:
Responsive Design üì±

Media queries apply CSS only when specific conditions (like screen size) are met.

@media (max-width: 600px) {
  body {
    background: blue;
  }
}
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Change the layout for mobile devices.

  1. Write a media query for screens with a max-width of 500px.
  2. Inside the query, target .container.
  3. Change its flex-direction to column.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Ensure your braces { } are correct. One set for the @media, and one set for the .container inside it.

/index.html.code:
A
B

exerciseContent.output: Boxes stack vertically when the preview window is narrow

exerciseContent.content:
Small Screens First üì≤

Mobile-first means writing CSS for mobile devices by default, then using min-width media queries to add complexity for larger screens.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

  1. Set the default font-size of h1 to 20px (for mobile).
  2. Create a media query for min-width: 768px.
  3. Inside it, set h1 font-size to 40px (for desktop).
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: min-width means 'apply this style if the screen is AT LEAST this wide'.

/index.html.code: Responsive Text

exerciseContent.output: Text gets larger as you widen the preview window

exerciseContent.content:
Bringing it to Life ‚ú®

You can animate elements using @keyframes.

@keyframes slide {
  from { left: 0; }
  to { left: 100px; }
}

Then apply it: animation: slide 2s infinite;
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Make the ball bounce.

  1. Define @keyframes bounce.
  2. At 0% set transform: translateY(0).
  3. At 50% set transform: translateY(-50px).
  4. At 100% set transform: translateY(0).
  5. Apply animation: bounce 1s infinite to the .ball.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: translateY moves items up (negative) and down (positive).
exerciseContent.output: A red ball moving up and down continuously

Hello World üåç

JavaScript makes pages interactive. We often use console.log() to print messages to the browser's developer tools for testing.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

In the script.js file:

  1. Write console.log('Hello Codebox');
  2. Write console.log(10 + 5);
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Don't forget the quotes for text strings! Numbers don't need quotes.

/index.html.code: Check the Console

exerciseContent.output: Output 'Hello Codebox' and '15' in the console

exerciseContent.content:
Storing Data üíæ

Use variables to remember values.

  • let: For values that can change.
  • const: For values that stay the same.

Types: String ('Text'), Number (42), Boolean (true/false).
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

  1. Create a const named appName with value 'Codebox'.
  2. Create a let named score with value 0.
  3. Update score to be 10.
  4. Log both to the console.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: You don't use 'let' again when updating a variable. Just score = 10;.

/index.html.code: Variables & Data Types

exerciseContent.output: Console logs 'Codebox' and '10'

exerciseContent.content:
Math & Logic üßÆ

JavaScript supports standard math (+, -, *, /) and comparison operators.

  • ===: Equal to (strict).
  • !==: Not equal to.
  • > / <: Greater/Less than.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

  1. Create a variable total that equals 100 + 50.
  2. Create a variable isWinner that checks if total > 140.
  3. Log isWinner (it should be true).
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Comparison operators return a boolean (true or false).

/index.html.code: JavaScript Operators

exerciseContent.output: Console logs 'true'

exerciseContent.content:
Fixing Bugs üêû

Things break. The console is your best friend. Besides log, you can use:

  • console.warn(): Prints a yellow warning.
  • console.error(): Prints a red error.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

Simulate an application status:

  1. Log 'System starting...'
  2. Warn 'Low memory'
  3. Error 'System crash!'
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Use the different methods exactly like console.log.

/index.html.code: Console & Debugging

exerciseContent.output: A normal log, a yellow warning, and a red error in the console

exerciseContent.content:
Thinking in Components ‚öõÔ∏è

React apps are built of components. A component is just a JavaScript function that returns HTML (called JSX).

function Welcome() {
  return <h1>Hello!</h1>;
}
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

  1. Inside App.js, change the App function.
  2. Make it return an <h1> that says 'My React App'.
  3. Add a <p> below it saying 'Components are cool'.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: If returning multiple lines, wrap them in a <div> or fragment <>...</>.
exerciseContent.output: React renders a Heading and a Paragraph

exerciseContent.content:
JSX: JS + XML üß¨

JSX allows you to write HTML in JS. But it's smarter.

You can embed variables using curly braces {}.

const name = "Alice";
return <h1>Hello {name}</h1>;
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

  1. Create a constant user with your name.
  2. Inside the return statement, display 'Welcome, [your name]' using the variable.
  3. Perform math inside curly braces to display '2 + 2 is {2 + 2}'.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Anything inside {} is executed as JavaScript.
exerciseContent.output: Displays 'Welcome [Name]' and '2 + 2 is 4'

exerciseContent.content:
Passing Data with Props üöö

Props (properties) allow you to pass data from a parent component to a child.

function Welcome(props) {
  return <h1>Hello, {props.name}</h1>;
}

Usage: <Welcome name="Alice" />
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

  1. Look at the Greeting component defined at the top.
  2. In the App component, render Greeting three times.
  3. Pass a different name prop to each one (e.g., 'Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie').
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: You use components like HTML tags: <Greeting name="..." />.
exerciseContent.output: Three different greeting messages

exerciseContent.content:
Lists and Keys üîë

To render a list, use the JavaScript map() method.

items.map(item => <li key={item.id}>{item.text}</li>)

Note: Always provide a unique key prop for list items so React can track them efficiently.
exerciseContent.task:
Your Task:

  1. Use .map() on the fruits array.
  2. For each fruit, return an <li> containing the fruit name.
  3. Use the fruit name itself as the key.
exerciseContent.hint: üí° Hint: Use curly braces to switch to JS mode inside the UL: <ul> { fruits.map(...) } </ul>.
exerciseContent.output: A bulleted list displaying Apple, Banana, and Cherry
